case_name: Ram Bilas Singh, Ram Naresh Singh and Dinesh Singh v. State

facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 73 of 1961 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 3, 1960 of the Patna High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 326 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 73 of 1961. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 3, 1960 of the Patna High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 326 of 1958.

facts.text: Patna High Court altered the conviction of the appellants under s. 304, Part II read with s. 149 IPC into convictions under s. 326 read with s. 149 IPC but maintained the sentences and affirmed convictions under s. 147 and s. 426 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by special leave from a judgment of the High Court of Patna altering the convinction of the appellants under s. 304, Part 11 read with s. 149 of the Indian Penal Code into convictions under s. 326 read with s. 149, I.P.C. but maintaining the sentences and affirming the conv

facts.text: There was a dispute between Ram Bilas Singh and his two sons Ram Naresh Singh and Dinesh Singh on the one hand and Deva Singh PW 2 and his brothers on the other with respect to a Dochara in village Dihara.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution case was that there was a dispute between Ram Bilas Singh of Shahpore and, his two sons Ram Naresh Singh and Dinesh Singh on the one hand  appellants before us  and Deva Singh  P. W. 2  and his brothers on the other with respect to a Dochara in a village Dihara.

facts.text: On April 22, 1957, at about 9.00 a.m., Deva Singh, Laldeo Singh (deceased), Dhunmun Singh PW 4 and Dasain Hajam were sitting in the Dochara.

anchor.surface_text: On April 22, 1957, at about 9.00 a.m. while Deva Singh, along with his brother Laldeo Singh, the deceased and two other persons Dhunmun Singh  P. W. 4  and Dasain Hajam were sitting in the Dochara

facts.text: Appellant No. 1 Ram Bilas Singh arrived at the Dochara in a truck with a mob of 40 to 50 persons including the other two appellants and four other persons acquitted by the trial court.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant No. 1 Ram Bilas Singh arrived there in a truck with a mob of 40 to 50 persons which included the other two appellants before us, besides four other persons who were acquitted by the trial court.

facts.text: Ram Bilas Singh fired from the gun he was carrying, hitting Laldeo Singh on the chest, causing him to fall down but he got up later.

anchor.surface_text: Ram Bilas Singh is said to have fired from the gun which he was carrying which hit Laldeo Singh on the chest as a result of which he fell down, but got up later.

facts.text: Ramdeo Singh (acquitted) fired from his gun and the shot hit Laldeo Singh on the chest, causing him to fall down again.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon Ramdeo Singh  acquitted by the trial court  fired from his gun and the shot hit Laldeo Singh on the chest and he fell down again.

facts.text: Ram Bilas Singh Gumasta of Dihara (acquitted) fired a second shot from his gun hitting Laldeo Singh on the abdomen, killing him instantaneously.

anchor.surface_text: After that, Ram Bilas Singh Gumasta of Dihara  acquitted by the trial court  fired a second shot from his gun hitting Laldeo Singh on the abdomen and killing him instantaneously.

facts.text: Appellant Ram Bilas Singh fired two shots at Deva Singh hitting him on his right thigh.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Ram Bilas Singh is further said to have fired two shots at Deva Singh hitting him on his right thigh.

facts.text: Appellants Ram Naresh Singh and Dinesh Singh assaulted Deva Singh with lathis, as a result of which he fell down.

anchor.surface_text: Appellants Ram Naresh Singh and Dinesh Singh are said to have assaulted Deva Singh with lathis as a result of which he fell down

facts.text: The mob dismantled the Dochara by demolishing its mud pillars, causing the thatched roof to fall down.

anchor.surface_text: and thereafter the mob proceeded to dismantle the Dochara by demolishing its mud pillars, as a result of which its thatched roof fell down.

facts.text: The mob took away a palang, a bamboo cot, two quilts, one lantern and one garansa.

anchor.surface_text: Having achieved their object, the mob is said to have left the place, taking away along with them a palang, a bamboo cot, two quilts, one lantern and one garansa.

facts.text: Villagers including Jagdish Singh, Bhagwat Singh (since dead) and Ajodhya Singh arrived at the spot after the incident.

anchor.surface_text: The incident attracted it number of villagers to the spot including jagdish Singh, Bhagwat Singh  since dead  and Ajodhya Singh.

facts.text: After report was lodged, police arrived, held panchnama inquest on body of Laldeo Singh and followed usual procedure.

anchor.surface_text: After report was lodged of the incident, the police arrived on the spot, held the panchnama  inquest  on the body of Lal Deo Singh and followed the usual procedure.

facts.text: Search was made for seven accused including appellants, arrested later, placed before magistrate who committed them for trial under ss. 148, 302/149, 426 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: A search was made for the seven accused persons, including the appellants, but it took some time to find them out and arrest them. Eventually, they were placed before a magistrate who committed them for trial for offences under s. 148, s. 302 read with s. 149 and s. 426, I.P.C.

facts.text: Specific charges: Ram Bilas Singh, Ramdeo Singh, Ram Bilas Singh Gumasta charged under s.302 IPC for murder of Laldeo Singh; Ram Bilas under s.307 for attempt murder Deva; Ram Naresh & Dinesh under s.323 for assaulting Dhunmun Singh PW4.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant Ram Bilas Singh, Ramdeo Singh and Ram Bilas Singh Gumasta of Dihara were specifically charged with offences under s. 302, I.P.C. for having committed the murder of Laldeo Singh. Ram Bilas Singh was further charged under s. 307 of the Indian Penal Code for attempt to commit the murder of Deva Singh while Ram Naresh Singh and Dinesh Singh  appellants 2 and 3  were further charged with offences under s. 323, I.P.C. for assaulting Dhunmun Singh  P. W. 4 .

facts.text: Sessions Court acquitted Ram Bilas Singh and Ramdeo Singh of s.302 IPC, all seven of 302/149; convicted three appellants under 304 Pt II /149, 147, 426 IPC; acquitted appellants 2&3 of s.323.

anchor.surface_text: The Court of Session acquitted both Ram Bilas Singh as well as Ramdeo Singh of the offence under s. 302, I. P.C. and also acquitted all the seven accused persons of the offence under s. 302 read with s. 149, I.P.C. It, however, convicted the three appellants before us under s. 304, second part, read with s. 149 of the I.P.C. and under ss. 147 and 426, I.P.C. but acquitted the appellants 2 and 3 of the offence under s. 323, I.P.C.

facts.text: Defence of appellants: Ram Bilas Singh was in possession of the dochara; Laldeo and Deva threatened to dismantle it; appellants marched with 15-20 persons carrying weapons.

anchor.surface_text: Briefly stated, the defence of the three appellants was that the appellant Ram Bilas Singh was in possession of the dochara, that it was Laldeo Singh and Deva Singh who threatened to dismantle the dochara and, therefore, they marched there on the date of the incident at the head of a mob consisting of 15 or 20 persons carrying with them various weapons.

facts.text: In defence version, Laldeo and Deva flourished farsis and gandasas; others used lathis and spears injuring four on appellants' side.

anchor.surface_text: During the incident, Laldeo Singh and Deva Singh are said to have flourished their farsis and gandasas while some other members of their party are said to have used their lathis and spears as a result of which four persons on the side of the appellants received injuries.

facts.text: In self-defence, Ram Lakhan Singh (deceased) fired a shot from his gun hitting Laldeo and Deva; Laldeo dropped dead, mob dispersed.

anchor.surface_text: In the meantime, in self-defence, one Ram Lakhan Singh  since deceased  fired a shot from his gun and ran away. This shot is said to have hit Laldeo Singh and also Deva Singh. After being injured in this manner, Laldeo Singh is said to have dropped down dead and then the mob dispersed.

facts.text: Both courts below rejected the defence that appellants were in possession of the dochara and that Laldeo and Deva were aggressors.

anchor.surface_text: The defence of the appellants that they were in possession of the dochara and that Laldeo Singh and Deva Singh were the aggressors has been rejected by both the courts below

facts.text: Prosecution case in charge sheet against seven named persons: three appellants, Ram Bilas Singh Gumasta, Sudarshan Singh s/o Ram Bilas Gumasta, Ramdeo Singh, Sakal Singh s/o Raghoo Singh.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel points out that the clear case of the prosecution in the charge sheet was against seven named persons i.e., the three appellants before us, Ram Bilas Singh Gumasta of Dihara, Sudarshan Singh son of Ram Bilas Singh Gumasta, Ramdeo Singh and Sakal Singh sons of Raghoo Singh

facts.text: Four of the seven accused were acquitted by trial court.

anchor.surface_text: and contends that out of these, four persons having been acquitted, the remaining three persons could not be said to have been members-of an unlawful assembly

facts.text: Hearing date: January 29, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: 1963. January 29.

issues.text: Whether the appellants could be convicted under s. 326 read with s. 149, I.P.C. despite acquittal under s. 302 read with s. 149, I.P.C. and individual acquittals under ss. 302 and 307, I.P.C.

anchor.surface_text: His contention, however, is that the appellants having been acquitted of the offence under s. 302 read with s. 149, I. P. C. and appellant No. 1 having been acquitted of the offences under s. 302 and s. 307, I.P.C. none of them could be convicted under s. 326 read with s. 149, I.P.C. Learned counsel points out that the clear case of the prosecution in the charge sheet was against seven named persons i.e., the three appellants before us, Ram Bilas Singh Gumasta of Dihara, Sudarshan Singh son of Ram Bilas Singh Gumasta, Ramdeo Singh and Sakal Singh sons of Raghoo Singh and contends that out of these, four persons having been acquitted, the remaining three persons could not be said to have been members-of an unlawful assembly and, therefore, they could neither e convicted under s. 147 I.P.C. nor could they be convicted of any other offences with the aid of s. 149, I. P.C.

issues.text: Whether, out of seven named accused in the prosecution case, the remaining three after acquittal of four could be said to be members of an unlawful assembly so as to be convicted under s. 147 I.P.C. or other offences with aid of s. 149 I.P.C.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel points out that the clear case of the prosecution in the charge sheet was against seven named persons i.e., the three appellants before us, Ram Bilas Singh Gumasta of Dihara, Sudarshan Singh son of Ram Bilas Singh Gumasta, Ramdeo Singh and Sakal Singh sons of Raghoo Singh and contends that out of these, four persons having been acquitted, the remaining three persons could not be said to have been members-of an unlawful assembly and, therefore, they could neither e convicted under s. 147 I.P.C. nor could they be convicted of any other offences with the aid of s. 149, I. P.C. All that it was competent for the court to do was to convict each of them for their individual acts and no more. Learned counsel further contends that without setting aside the acquittal of the four alleged associates of the appellants, there could be no finding to the effect that there was an unlawful assembly of which the appellants were members and were, therefore, liable for the acts of other members thereof.

issues.text: Whether there could be a finding of an unlawful assembly without setting aside the acquittal of the four alleged associates.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel further contends that without setting aside the acquittal of the four alleged associates of the appellants, there could be no finding to the effect that there was an unlawful assembly of which the appellants were members and were, therefore, liable for the acts of other members thereof. Further, it was urged by learned counsel that an accused person cannot be held liable vicariously for the act of an acquitted person and, therefore, even assuming that the fatal injuries were caused to Laldeo Singh by one of the four acquitted persons,

issues.text: Whether an accused person can be held vicariously liable under s. 149 I.P.C. for the act of an acquitted person.

anchor.surface_text: liable vicariously for the act of an acquitted person and, therefore, even assuming that the fatal injuries were caused to Laldeo Singh by one of the four acquitted persons, it was not open to the High Court to hold any of the appellants liable for that act with the aid of s. 149, I.P.C.

issues.text: Whether the High Court rightly altered the convictions and affirmed unlawful assembly findings without properly considering the evidence and prosecution case limited to seven named persons.

anchor.surface_text: Applying the law as set out above, we must find out whether what the High Court has done in this case is right. In the first place, though it was vaguely stated by some of the witnesses examined in the case that 40 or 50 persons took part in the incident including the 7 persons mentioned in the first information report and the charge sheet, the prosecution case throughout has been that only seven named persons took part in the incident.

issues.text: Whether there was an unlawful assembly of more than five persons including unidentified others, given the FIR and charge naming only seven and vague witness statements of 40-50.

anchor.surface_text: It was necessary for the High Court to consider whether the statements of some of the witnesses that the unlawful assembly consisted of many more than seven persons are true or whether they should be rejected in view of the fact that the first information report shows that only seven persons who were named therein, committed the offence. It had also to consider the further question of prejudice by reason of the defect in the charge.

arguments.court_reasoning: Possible if evidence supports individual acts, but here s.149 based convictions invalid

anchor.surface_text: Further, it was urged by learned counsel that an accused person cannot be held liable vicariously for the act of an acquitted person and, therefore, even assuming that the fatal injuries were caused to Laldeo Singh by one of the four acquitted persons, it was not open to the High Court to hold any of the appellants liable for that act with the aid of s. 149, I.P.C.

Rex which reads thus Now in a criminal case the burden of proof is always on the prosecution. It is for the prosecution to establish the responsibility of the accused for the crime alleged. Having regard to the fact that there is no appeal against the acquittal

arguments.court_reasoning: Supports principle that acquittal prevents vicarious liability without other evidence

arguments.claim: If only named persons in charge/FIR and less than 5 after acquittals, no unlawful assembly under s.149 (synthesizing precedents like Topandas, Plummer)

anchor.surface_text: In Topandas v. The State of Bombay, this court has held that where four named individuals were charged with having committed an offence of criminal conspiracy under s. 120-B, P.C. and three out of those four were acquitted of that charge, the fourth accused could not be held guilty of the offence of criminal conspiracy.

arguments.claim: Unlawful assembly possible with unidentified others if FIR/evidence supports more than 5 despite acquittals (distinguishing Bharwad Mepa Dana, Kartar Singh)

anchor.surface_text: In Bharwad Mepa Dana v. State of Bombay, this court had to consider the correctness of the conviction of three persons under s. 302 read with s. 149 I.P.C. when one other person who had been convicted by the Sessions judge of a similar offence had been acquitted by the High Court. ... together numbered more than five.

arguments.claim: High Court erred by not properly considering evidence of unlawful assembly numbers, assuming it without analysis despite prosecution case limited to 7 named

anchor.surface_text: Applying the law as set out above, we must find out whether what the High Court has done in this case is right. In the first place, though it was vaguely stated by some of the witnesses examined in the case that 40 or 50 persons took part in the incident including the 7 persons mentioned in the first information report and the charge sheet,

arguments.claim: High Court should have examined entire evidence to find if unlawful assembly of 5+ including unidentified, but failed to do so

holdings.text: where the prosecution case as set out in the charge and as supported by the evidence is to the effect that the alleged unlawful assembly consists of five or more named persons and no others, and there is no question of any participation by other persons not identified or identifiable it is not open to the court to hold that there was an unlawful assembly unless it comes to the definite conclusion that five or more of the named persons were members thereof.

anchor.surface_text: The decisions of this court quoted above thus make it clear that where the prosecution case as set out in the charge and as supported by the evidence is to the effect that the alleged unlawful assembly consists of five or more named persons and no others, and there is no question of any participation by other persons not identified or identifiable it is not open to the court to hold that there was an unlawful assembly unless it comes to the definite conclusion that five or more of the named persons were members thereof.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Synthesised from precedents such as Topandas v. State of Bombay and Plummer where conviction requires proof of 5+ members and acquittals reduce named persons below threshold without other evidence.

holdings.text: Where, however, the case of the prosecution and the evidence adduced indicates that a number in excess of five persons participated in the incident and some of them could not be identified, it would be open to the court to convict less than five of the offence of being members of the unlawful assembly or convict them of the offence committed by the unlawful assembly with the aid of s 149, I. P. C. provided, it comes to the conclusion that five or more persons participated in the incident.

anchor.surface_text: Where, however, the case of the prosecution and the evidence adduced indicates that a number in excess of five persons participated in the incident and some of them could not be identified, it would be open to the court to convict less than five of the offence of being members of the unlawful assembly or convict them of the offence committed by the unlawful assembly with the aid of s 149, I. P. C. provided, it comes to the conclusion that five or more persons participated in the incident.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Drawn from Bharwad Mepa Dana, Kartar Singh, and Mohan Singh where evidence or FIR indicated larger assembly including unidentified persons.

holdings.text: when a person has been acquitted of an offence, his acquittal will be good for all purposes when the incident in connection with which he was implicated comes up for consideration before the High Court in appeal by a person or persons who were tried along with him and convicted of some offence with the aid of s. 149, I. P. C.

anchor.surface_text: Again, it is clear from these decisions that when a person has been acquitted of an offence, his acquittal will be good for all purposes when the incident in connection with which he was implicated comes up for consideration before the High Court in appeal by a person or persons who were tried along with him and convicted of some offence with the aid of s. 149, I. P. C.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Consistent application of precedents treating acquittal as final in appeals by co-accused; Sunder Singh exception noted but not necessary to resolve consistency with Plummer.

holdings.text: it is competent to a court to come to the conclusion that there was an unlawful assembly of five or more persons, even if less than that number have been convicted by it if a the charge states that apart from the persons named, several other unidentified persons were also members of the unlawful assembly whose common object was to commit an unlawful act and evidence led to prove this is accepted by the court b or that the first information report and the evidence shows such to be the case even though the charge does not state so, c or that though the charge and the prosecution witnesses named only the acquitted and the convicted accused persons there is other evidence which discloses the existence of named or other persons provided, in cases b and c, no prejudice has resulted to the convicted person by reason of the omission to mention in the charge that the other unnamed persons had also participated in the offence.

anchor.surface_text: Thus all the decisions of this court to which we have referred make it clear that it is competent to a court to come to the conclusion that there was an unlawful assembly of five or more persons, even if less than that number have been convicted by it if a the charge states that apart from the persons named, several other unidentified persons were also members of the unlawful assembly whose common object was to commit an unlawful act and evidence led to prove this is accepted by the court b or that the first information report and the evidence shows such to be the case even though the charge does not state so,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Comprehensive conditions derived from Mohan Singh, Dalip Singh, and related precedents specifying scenarios where s.149 viable despite acquittals.

holdings.text: It was necessary for the High Court to consider whether the statements of some of the witnesses that the unlawful assembly consisted of many more than seven persons are true or whether they should be rejected in view of the fact that the first information report shows that only seven persons who were named therein, committed the offence. It had also to consider the further question of prejudice by reason of the defect in the charge.

anchor.surface_text: It was necessary for the High Court to consider whether the statements of some of the witnesses that the unlawful assembly consisted of many more than seven persons are true or whether they should be rejected in view of the fact that the first information report shows that only seven persons who were named therein, committed the offence. It had also to consider the further question of prejudice by reason of the defect in the charge.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prosecution case and FIR confined to seven named persons; vague witness statements required scrutiny which High Court omitted.

holdings.text: Had the High Court, come to a reasoned conclusion that there was an unlawful assembly consisting of more than five persons, including the appellants and some other persons who were unidentified and convicted the appellants under s. 147 and, with the aid of s. 149, also of some other offence committed by a member or members of the unlawful assembly other than the acquitted persons the matter would have stood on a different footing. But it has not done so.

anchor.surface_text: Had the High Court, come to a reasoned conclusion that there was an unlawful assembly consisting of more than five persons, including the appellants and some other persons who were unidentified and convicted the appellants under s. 147 and, with the aid of s. 149, also of some other offence committed by a member or members of the unlawful assembly other than the acquitted persons the matter would have stood on a different footing. But it has not done so.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court proceeded on assumption without evidence analysis or reasoned finding on unlawful assembly composition, rendering convictions under ss. 326/149, 147 unsustainable.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel relied upon a passage in the judgment of Agarwala J., in Harchanda v. Rex which reads thus Now in a criminal case the burden of proof is always on the prosecution. It is for the prosecution to establish the responsibility of the accused for the crime alleged. Having regard to the fact that there is noappeal against the acquittal of the other five accused before us, and having regard to the fact that we cannot I.L.R.  1951  2 All. 62, 73.

precedents.cited_proposition: Accused cannot be held constructively liable for infliction of wounds by acquitted persons or unknown persons when prosecution fails to explain
precedents.cited_holding: the prosecution is unable to explain the infliction of the incised wounds. in my opinion in such a case the accused cannot be held constructively liable for the infliction of those wounds.

precedents.citation: Topandas v. The State of Bombay 19552 S.C.R. 881

anchor.surface_text: In Topandas v. The State of Bombay 1 , this court has held that where four named individuals were charged with having committed an offence of criminal conspiracy under s. 120-B, P.C. and three out of those four were acquitted of that charge, the fourth accused could not be held guilty of the offence of criminal conspiracy. In support of this view, this court ha-, relied upon a passage in Archbalds Criminal Pleading, Evidence and Practice 33rd edn.p. 201, paragraph 361  which reads thus Where several prisoners are included in the same indictment, the jury may find one guilty and acquit the others, and vice versa. But if several are indicated for a riot, and the jury acquit all but two, they must acquit those two also, unless it is charged in the indictment and proved, that they committed the riot together with some other person not tried upon that  1  19552 S.C.R. 881.

precedents.cited_proposition: Where four named persons charged with criminal conspiracy and three acquitted, the fourth cannot be convicted of conspiracy

anchor.surface_text: This court has also quoted with approval a passage from the judgment in R. v. Plummer 1 , which is one of the decisions on which the above passage is founded. 1  1902 2 K.B 339.

precedents.cited_proposition: If several indicted for riot and all but two acquitted, must acquit the two unless proved they acted with others not tried; similar for conspiracy

precedents.citation: Bharwad Mepa Dana v. State of Bombay 1960 2 S.C.R. 172, 181

anchor.surface_text: In Bharwad Mepa Dana v. State of Bombay 2 , this court had to consider the correctness of the conviction of three persons under s. 302 read with s. 149 I.P.C. when one other person who had been convicted by the Sessions judge of a similar offence had been acquitted by the High Court. ...  2  1960 2 S.C.R. 172, 181.

precedents.case_name: Bharwad Mepa Dana v State of Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: Unlawful assembly can consist of convicted persons and unidentified others even if some named acquitted, if more than five participated
precedents.cited_holding: the appellants before it were rightly convicted under s. 302 read with s. 149, I.P.C., and that there was nothing in law which prevented the High Court from finding that the unlawful assembly consisted of the four convicted persons and some unidentified persons

precedents.citation: Kartar Singh v. State of Punjab 1962 2 S.C.R. 395. 399

anchor.surface_text: Then, there is the decision of this court in Kartar Singh v. State of Punjab 1 , where this court has held that if the trial court can legally find that the actual number of members in the assailants party was more than five, that party will in law constitute an unlawful assembly even though ultimately three of the accused persons are convicted. ... 1  1962 2 S.C.R. 395. 399.

precedents.case_name: Kartar Singh v State of Punjab
precedents.cited_proposition: If more than five assailants even if some convicted, constitutes unlawful assembly; but if definite named less than five after acquittals, no
precedents.cited_holding: it is only when the number of the alleged assailants is definite and all of them are named and the number of persons found to have taken part in the incident is less than five, it cannot be held that they formed an unlawful assembly.

precedents.citation: Dalip Singh v. State of Punjab 1954 S.C.R. 145

precedents.case_name: Dalip Singh v State of Punjab

precedents.citation: Sunder Singh v. State of Punjab 1962 Supp. 2 S.C.R. 654. 663

anchor.surface_text: In Sunder Singh v. State of Punjab 2  , also this court has considered the effect of the acquittal of some persons of the offence under s. 302 read with s. 149, I.P.C. on the conviction of the remaining persons who numbered less than five. ...  2  1962 Supp. 2 S.C.R. 654. 663.

precedents.case_name: Sunder Singh v State of Punjab
precedents.cited_proposition: Effect of acquittal of some named members on remaining for s.149; High Court can consider incidentally acquitted persons under s.423 CrPC
precedents.cited_holding: if in dealing with a case before it, it became necessary for the High Court to deal indirectly or incidentally with the case against the acquitted accused, it could well do so and there is no legal bar to such a course.

anchor.surface_text: Upon the facts of the case before it, this court held that the principle set out in Plummers case 3 ,  3  1902 2 K B. 339.

precedents.cited_proposition: Principle on acquittals in charges of riot or unlawful assembly with named persons

anchor.surface_text: did not apply to the case before it. This court then proceeded to consider the powers of the court of appeal under s. 423  1   a  of the Criminal Procedure Code and observed that if in dealing with a case before it, it became necessary for the High Court to deal indirectly or incidentally with the case against the acquitted accused, it could well do so and there is nolegal bar to such a course. Upon the view we are taking it is unnecessary to express any opinion as to whether the interpretation placed in this case upon the ambit of the powers under s. 423, Cr. P. C. is consistent with the principle in Plummers case 2 . 1  1955 2 S.C.R. 881.

precedents.case_name: Mohan Singh v State of Punjab
precedents.cited_proposition: Mere acquittal of some named does not invalidate s.149 if evidence shows unlawful assembly of 5+ including unidentified; but if confined to named and less than 5 after acquittal, cannot invoke s.149
precedents.cited_holding: In such cases, if both the charge and the evidence are confined to the persons named in the charge and out of the persons so named two or more are acquitted leaving before the court less than five persons to be tried, then s. 149 cannot be invoked.

anchor.surface_text: The decisions of this court quoted above thus make it clear that where the prosecution case as set out in the charge and as supported by the evidence is to the effect that the alleged unlawful assembly consists of five or more named persons and no others, and there is no question of any participation by other persons not identified or identifiable it is not open to the court to hold that there was an unlawful assembly unless it comes to the definite conclusion that five or more of the named persons were members thereof.

Applying the law as set out above, we must find out whether what the High Court has done in this case is right. In the first place, though it was vaguely stated by some of the witnesses examined in the case that 40 or 50 persons took part in the incident including the 7 persons mentioned in the first information report and the charge sheet, the prosecution case throughout has been that only seven named persons took part in the incident.

anchor.surface_text: Where, however, the case of the prosecution and the evidence adduced indicates that a number in excess of five persons participated in the incident and some of them could not be identified, it would be open to the court to convict less than five of the offence of being members of the unlawful assembly or convict them of the offence committed by the unlawful assembly with the aid of s 149, I. P. C. provided, it comes to the conclusion that five or more persons participated in the incident.
